headline: Cheyenne couple seeks support for family after barber taken into ICE custody
summary: ICE detained and deported Carlos Montes, a Nicaraguan barber in Cheyenne, following a Laramie County Sheriff's traffic stop, despite his employer's claim he had proper work authorization approved by Wyoming's Attorney General's office; the agency provided no information to his family for three weeks, illustrating systemic communication failures. Immigration attorney Elisabeth Trefonas confirmed removal orders can occur even when immigrants believe their documentation is valid, noting detainees are frequently transferred between facilities before accessing counsel. The Sheriff's Office confirmed deputies initiated the stop for an inoperable headlight and that "ICE authorized deputies to take Montes into custody." The case reflects the Trump administration's termination of Temporary Protected Status for Nicaraguans and increased deportation efforts, creating a climate of rapid detention with limited due process. Montes' employer and community have rallied support, highlighting the human and economic toll on families and small businesses when immigration enforcement operates with minimal transparency.

headline: Amid ICE agent abuse arrests in Ohio, advocate says it ‘fails to police its own ranks’
summary: An Ohio immigration advocate is demanding ICE explain its agent screening procedures after two Ohio-based agents were convicted or charged with abusing women, raising concerns that rapid agency expansion may be compromising vetting standards. One agent received a 12-year sentence for coercing sex from immigrant women under his supervision, while another was charged with domestic violence after police responded to his home 23 times in 18 months. The advocate questions whether ICE requires agents to report law enforcement scrutiny and criticizes the agency for failing to police its own ranks while targeting immigrants with minor or no criminal records. These incidents highlight significant policy gaps in oversight and accountability within federal immigration enforcement.

headline: RIPTA once again counts on Gov. McKee to fill its budget gap
summary: RIPTA’s $158.9 million FY2027 budget faces a nearly $14 million deficit, prompting submission to Gov. McKee and state lawmakers for gap funding. State intervention—including a 2-cent gas tax hike and increased Highway Maintenance Account share—previously reduced the deficit from $39.8 million. Board member Normand Benoit advocated for a “millionaires tax” on high earners to fill the remaining shortfall, a proposal with legislative support that failed last session. The budget assumes revenue from a fare increase, though advocates warn this could reduce ridership and offset revenue gains. The outcome hinges on state political dynamics, including skepticism about the Governor’s commitment and debate over taxation versus spending cuts.

headline: Missouri faces budget crunch as capital gains tax cut hits harder than expected
summary: Missouri's capital gains tax cut will cost $500 million this year—far exceeding the $160 million estimate—pushing revenues down 2.1% to $13.15 billion and creating a $2.6 billion deficit against current spending of $15.7 billion. Governor Kehoe will tap the state's surplus to cushion the shortfall while pursuing income tax elimination, a move Democrats oppose, warning it will force cuts to Medicaid, education, and public safety net services.

headline: Health Department warns of measles exposure in Rapid City
summary: The South Dakota Department of Health warned of potential measles exposure at Rapid City Regional Airport, bringing the state's 2024 case total to 15; State Epidemiologist Joshua Clayton highlighted that kindergarten vaccination rates have fallen from 97% to 90% over the past decade amid misinformation and rising religious exemptions, with 13 of the 15 cases occurring among unvaccinated individuals.

headline: Immigration arrests in WA surged in recent months
summary: ICE arrests in Washington surged to over 950 between July 29 and Oct. 15, bringing the total since Trump's inauguration to nearly 2,000—more than double last year's figure—while the share of detainees with criminal convictions dropped to 31% despite federal targeting claims. Senator Patty Murray and the ACLU condemned alleged abuses, including a detainee mauled by a police dog, as the crackdown intensified following Congress's $170 billion funding allocation for Trump's immigration agenda. Deportation flights from Boeing Field increased to 3-4 per week, raising overcrowding concerns at Tacoma's 1,575-bed detention center, which holds over 1,300 people. State inspectors remain barred from the facility despite a court ruling in their favor, amid ongoing allegations of medical neglect and mistreatment. The issue is poised to dominate Washington's legislative session starting next month as lawmakers debate enhanced immigrant protections.

headline: Judge orders bond hearing for detained immigration rights activist Jeanette Vizguerra
summary: A federal judge ordered ICE to provide a constitutionally adequate bond hearing by Christmas Eve for immigrant rights activist Jeanette Vizguerra, who has been detained in Aurora since March. The government must prove she poses a flight risk or danger to justify continued detention. The judge noted her prolonged detention raises exceptional constitutional concerns, resembles criminal incarceration, and suggests ICE may have acted with punitive intent rather than as an impartial decisionmaker, potentially in retaliation for her advocacy.

headline: No justification for second boat strike, Rep. Crow says after viewing unedited video
summary: Congressional Democrats urging refusal of illegal orders faced presidential accusations of sedition and calls for execution, potentially escalating political tensions toward civil unrest.

outlet: News From The States - Fair. Fearless. Free.
headline: Trump administration policy blocked that limited congressional visits to ICE facilities
summary: A federal judge temporarily blocked a DHS policy requiring seven days' notice for congressional visits to immigrant detention facilities, finding it violated Section 527 of the 2019 appropriations law which permits unannounced oversight. The ruling, which grants a stay while the case proceeds, stems from a lawsuit by 12 Democratic lawmakers challenging the Trump administration's restriction on oversight of immigration enforcement amid rising detention numbers. The decision preserves legislators' ability to conduct real-time monitoring of detention conditions.

headline: Scott administration pitches $75 million buydown to help offset property tax spike
summary: The Scott administration proposes allocating $75 million in unused, rolled-over state budget funds to offset a projected 12% property tax increase, continuing a recent practice of using one-time money (over $100 million last year) that critics warn creates a fiscal hole and delays structural reforms to education funding; the proposal requires legislative approval and is tied to implementation of Act 73's education governance changes.

headline: ACLU sues ICE, alleging agency violates constitutional rights of observers and protesters
summary: The ACLU of Minnesota sued ICE alleging systematic violations of protesters' First and Fourth Amendment rights during immigration raids, claiming agents under a Trump administration operation used excessive force, warrantless detentions, and law enforcement databases to track license plates and home addresses as intimidation. The lawsuit seeks a temporary restraining order to halt practices including handcuffing observers in snow, pointing guns at a couple in their 60s, and pepper-spraying a citizen filming arrests, arguing these tactics chill constitutional freedoms.

headline: Lots happening in the Crooked Letter State…
summary: Mississippi public university sports programs could be venues for protests over hiring decisions or coaching legacies.

headline: Auditor: Half of state education money should go toward raising teacher pay
summary: Mississippi State Auditor Shad White proposes allocating 50% of the state's K-12 budget to teacher salaries, which would fund at least an $8,000 raise for educators who currently rank 40th nationally in starting pay and third-lowest when adjusted for cost of living. The proposal comes after a 2022 pay raise was eroded by inflation and insurance premium increases, leaving teachers earning less than during the Great Recession when adjusted for inflation. House Speaker Jason White has indicated education will be the headline issue in the upcoming legislative session, though teacher pay increases may be entangled with controversial school choice measures in an omnibus bill. Teacher organizations report that low pay is driving thousands of vacancies across the state, resulting in larger class sizes and less individualized instruction. The auditor's office notes that assistant teachers also face substandard pay, compounding staffing challenges in Mississippi's public schools.

headline: Mississippi woman battles a curable disease in prison as friend amplifies her story
summary: Mississippi prisons face a public health crisis as hundreds of incarcerated individuals with hepatitis C are denied treatment despite a 95% cure rate and CDC recommendations, with only 48 of 19,000 prisoners receiving care in a recent period; State Health Officer Dr. Daniel Edney warns untreated disease will spill into communities upon release, Corrections Chairwoman Rep. Becky Currie calls it a public health crisis, and systemic failures persist in the state's $357 million contract with VitalCore Health Strategies.

headline: Measles cases rise amid holiday travel
summary: Measles cases have surged to 1,958 across 43 states through December 16, threatening the U.S. eradication status declared in 2000, as vaccination rates fall below the 95% threshold needed to limit spread; the CDC reports that vaccine hesitancy—exacerbated by political figures including Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.—and competing priorities have driven outbreaks in Texas (803 cases), South Carolina (142 cases with 168 people quarantined), and other states, while the agency's own social media communication about the disease has dropped significantly, and state health departments urge employer accommodations for quarantined workers.

headline: Kansas House, Senate budget panel launches exploration of ‘questionable’ university spending
summary: House Appropriations Committee Chairman Troy Waymaster is leading a legislative review of potentially wasteful spending at Kansas universities to identify cost savings and improve accountability for taxpayer dollars, with the oversight effort set to expand across state agencies in the 2026 session.

headline: Trackers, AI translators, pepper spray: Cabinet approves cops’ immigration requests
summary: Florida's State Board of Immigration Enforcement unanimously approved $2.4 million in new immigration enforcement grants for ten local agencies, bringing total allocations to roughly $21 million of the $250 million diverted by the Legislature in February. The funding covers equipment such as AI language translators, GPS trackers, DNA testing machines, tactical gear, and officer bonuses. Martin County Sheriff's Office received the largest share ($738,451) for wide-ranging immigration activities, while Volusia County Corrections obtained $505,789 for detention beds, 287(g) officer training, and screening systems. The grants implement February legislation requiring all Florida counties to partner with ICE, establishing state penalties for undocumented entry, and eliminating in-state tuition for undocumented students. Florida was the first state to establish a migrant detention facility, "Alligator Alcatraz," following the legislative crackdown.

headline: Michigan Senate passes bipartisan funding supplement to offset House GOP cuts
summary: The Michigan Senate passed House Bill 4576 appropriating $634 million to restore FY2026 funding that House Republicans cut using a rarely-used provision to unilaterally disapprove $645 million in work projects; the bill now returns to the House where Speaker Matt Hall is unlikely to schedule a vote despite bipartisan support shown by five Senate Republicans breaking ranks, while Senate Democrats have formally challenged the constitutionality of the Republican funding disapproval process.

headline: State Sen. Dan McKeon changes plea to not guilty on misdemeanor disturbing the peace charge
summary: Nebraska State Sen. Dan McKeon faces a misdemeanor disturbing-the-peace charge, downgraded from public indecency, after allegedly groping a legislative staffer at a party. The charge—commonly applied to protests and public demonstrations—illustrates how peace disturbance statutes can be used in cases of alleged official misconduct. McKeon now pleads not guilty after his initial no-contest plea was rejected, while also facing potential legislative expulsion following a unanimous Executive Board recommendation and gubernatorial calls for his resignation, highlighting significant political and institutional consequences.
